issue.title: Brightness fluctuations with gpu-next, HDR10+ Profile B
issue.body:
### Important Information

Provide following Information:
- mpv version: Nightly from 22.10.2023, Shinchiro build, libmpv-2.dll
- Windows Version: 11
- Source of the mpv binary: see above
- If known which version of mpv introduced the problem: not sure

### Reproduction steps

I have 2 videos encoded with HDR10+ Profile B and both show strange brightness fluctuations with gpu-next. Brightness (and probably colors) are changing repeatedly and constantly. It's very visible, from dark to bright and vice versa. HDR10+ Profile A files seem to display correctly.

Is this a known issue?

comment.body:
If you can reproduce at specific timestamps you can ue either of ffmpeg or MKVToolNix to extract that part out into a smaller file.
It has to be under 512M.

> why not use macros?

You mean the `MP_TIME` macros? Sure, I can change it.

> do we know on which platforms this might even be needed?

Not sure, I haven't dealt with the timer code much.

> Maybe we just should remove this implementation detail of our timer?

Glancing at it, we probably can.

pull_request.title: timer: properly parenthesize macro
pull_request.body: otherwise, it may give wrong/unwanted results due to operator precedence when used in arithmetic expressions.

pull_request.title: timer: properly parenthesize macro
pull_request.body: otherwise, it may give wrong/unwanted results due to operator precedence when used in arithmetic expressions.

comment.body:
> I'd like to have longer names

After learning about the "mpv/" prefix along with looking at many cases where it's getting truncated *already*, I no longer really care about enforcing that. So feel free to add "mpv/" back or use longer names. :+1: 

> Why allocate memory here? It's just going to get truncated anyway.

Previously everything was truncated to 80 bytes regardless of the platform. But after Kasper's recent change, only the linux branch gets truncated on `ERANGE`.

pull_request.title: mp_threads: rename threads for consistent naming across all of them
mp_threads: rename threads for consistent naming across all of them
demux: don't deallocate the cache when exiting the player
pull_request.body:
The cache is stored as a linked list, containing possibly hundreds of thousands of small cached packets. Iterating over all of them and deallocating takes a significant amount of time, especially if this memory gets swapped out.

When exiting the player, there is no need to clear all of this, let the kernel reclaim the memory after the program exits.

This change significantly speeds up the closing time when a large demuxer cache is used.

Fixes: #12294, #12563

comment.body: By "log" I meant something like a debug log (e.g `MP_DBG` or `MP_TRACE`) which aren't enabled by default. But drop it if you don't think it's worth it.

This option does nothing when put inside config files.

issue.title: Support libsixel as a video output option
issue.body:
One of the most creative libraries I've seen recently for those of us who may not wish to use X is [`libsixel`](https://github.com/saitoha/libsixel). It allows for the output of images directly in a terminal which supports it. As mpv still supports image outputs, this would not be dramatically different.

In fact, there is already a fork of `ffmpeg` that supports libsixel playback, so such a thing is not beyond possibility. However, I cannot estimate how much time/work it would be to implement this feature. Rest assured, I would deeply appreciate it if it ever gets implemented!

comment.body: I ran into the same issue. Please make mpv able to display sixel by default. Sixel is great, now after 30 years Linux can finally do what my Commodore 64 could all the time: display graphics and command line in the same window : )

Hello! Firstly, thank you all. It is the best universal player.
But it lacks with one simple thing, let the volume stay intact, in a playlist at least.
It is so annoying, every lua script for that out there does not work right for me.
macos 14

commits.message:
player/audio: fix incorrect check on adding delay

dac977193cccbf7e2e999cf0c4b0292314839c4c changed adding delay to only
when the video is playing but this isn't correct. The video frames
adjust themselves based on the audio, so if we still have audio
processing while the video itself happens to be in some non-playing
state (such as STATUS_READY), the delay still needs to be taken into
account. The correct thing to check is to make sure that it is not
STATUS_EOF. STATUS_EOF covers the case where we have still image, and of
course no video at all is STATUS_EOF. So having a massive bogus delay
value is still avoided.

issue.title: kwin Wayland: Unable to enable VRR on 0.35.0?
issue.body:
### Important Information

Provide following Information:
- mpv version: mpv 0.35.0
- Linux Distribution and Version:  Fedora 37 KDE
- Source of the mpv binary:  Fedora repo
- If known which version of mpv introduced the problem: mpv 0.35.0
- Window Manager and version:  kwin 5.26.4 Wayland
- GPU driver and version: mesa 22.2.3

### Reproduction steps
My KDE's Adaptive Sync is set to `Automatic`. As of mpv 0.35.0 I assume I need to set `drm-vrr-enabled=yes` to enable Adaptive Sync, but it won't activate when mpv is fullscreened with it set.
If I downgrade to mpv 0.34.1, fullscreen still activates Adaptive Sync `Automatic`, so I know my system has the capability.

I tried changing mpv's entry in `/usr/share/drirc.d/00-mesa-defaults.conf` to true as well, but that didn't help 0.35.0.

Additionally, I'm still experiencing the Display FPS issue of #10444. But even while mpv is reporting 60 there, my monitor OSD says it's running at 72hz (24fps source) with fullscreen 0.34.1.
I included logs where I corrected for that issue before starting playback on both versions of mpv.

### Expected behavior
Active Adaptive Sync on 0.35.0 with `drm-vrr-enabled=yes`?
### Actual behavior
No Adaptive Sync despite `drm-vrr-enabled=yes` being set.
### Log file
[no-config_drm-vrr-enabled-yes_0-35-0.log](https://github.com/mpv-player/mpv/files/10191849/no-config_drm-vrr-enabled-yes_0-35-0.log)
[no-config_drm-vrr-enabled-yes_0-35.0_corrected_display_fps.log](https://github.com/mpv-player/mpv/files/10191850/no-config_drm-vrr-enabled-yes_0-35.0_corrected_display_fps.log)
[no-config_0-34-1.log](https://github.com/mpv-player/mpv/files/10191851/no-config_0-34-1.log)
[no-config_0-34.1_corrected_display_fps.log](https://github.com/mpv-player/mpv/files/10191852/no-config_0-34.1_corrected_display_fps.log)

comment.body: Well tell plasma to fix their automatic detection like I said above.

issue.title: Ideal --scale-antiring value for ringy polar filters?
issue.body:
Title. What's a good value that doesn't lead to too much artifacting/detail loss? Just curious if anyone who has done more testing has arrived at a nice value, since the mpv/libplacebo documentation doesn't give any recommendations. Discuss :)

Pseudo-continuation of the discussion from #12384

comment.body:
> Too strong antiring can create aliasing and an unnatural looking image:

I think it's important here to clarify whether or not AR actually _creates_ the aliasing, or if the source was aliased to begin with, and overshoot was simply masking it. In practice, the difference probably doesn't really matter, but it can help clarify whether or not even tweaking the AR strength helps mitigate the issue. Obviously, as you already clarified, the example here is super exaggerated, and I've noticed these unnatural cut-off artifacts myself with similar test images. But I still think the difference here is pretty important.

> Personally i've noticed that blurrier filters can get away with stronger antiringing without the issues becoming noticeable.

Interesting, I actually haven't tested this out myself. Something like `haasnsoft` can get away with higher AR values then? I know it's just a blurry `ewa_hanning`, but that's the first filter that comes to mind. Quadratic-windowed Jinc maybe?

It seems like the general consensus here is leaning towards somewhere between 0.50-0.75 AR, which is pretty much where the discussion last thread ended. Right now, I'm most interested in a source where AR strength highlights aliasing, because that might lead us closer to a definitive answer. I think on relatively grainy and/or clean sources, the difference in AR strength is just a matter of pixel-peeping, which we could do until the end of time.

I'm also curious if AR leads to those unnatural cut-off artifacts on realistic but still high scale factors (maybe like 4.5x with 480p -> 2160p?). I'm constrained to my own screen size here, so if anyone would like to chip into the discussion with that, it would be cool.
